Running title reads: The puritaine widdow.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.p: THE PVRITAINE Or THE WIDDOW of Watling-streete.
Acted by the Children of Paules.
Imprinted at London by G. ELD. 1607.

div.head: ACTVS PRIMVS.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Widdow-Plus, her two Daughters Franke and Moll, her husbands Brother an old Knight Sir Godfrey, with her Sonne and heyre Maister Edmond, all in moorning apparell, Edmond in a Cypresse Hatte. The Widdow wringing her hands, and bursting out into a passion, as newly come from the Buriall of her husband.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: OH, that euer I was borne, that euer I was borne!

sp.speaker: Sir Godfrey.
sp.p: Nay good Sister, deare sister, sweete sister, bee of good comfort, shew yourselfe a woman, now or neuer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, I haue lost the deerest man. I haue buried the sweetest husband that euer lay by woman.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay giue him his due hee was indeed an honest, vertuous, discreet wise-man,— hee was my Brother, as right, as right.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, I shall neuer forget him, neuer forget him, hee was a man so well giuen to a woman— oh:

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay but kinde Sister, I could weepe as much as any woman, but alas our teares cannot call him againe: me thinkes you are well read Sister, and know that death is as common as Homo a common name to all men;— a man shall bee taken when hee's making water,— Nay, did not the learned Parson Maister Pigman tell vs een now, that all Flesh is fraile, wee are borne to dye, Man ha's but a time: with such like deepe and profound perswasions, as hee is a rare fellow you know and an excellent Reader: and for example, (as there are examples aboundance,) did not Sir Humfrey Bubble dye tother day there's a lustie Widdow, why shee cryed not aboue halfe an houe-for shame, for shame: then followed him old Maister Fulsome the Vsurer, there's a wise Widdow, why shee cryed nere a whitte at all.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: O rancke not mee with those wicked women, I had a Husband out-shinde 'em all.

sp.speaker: Syr Godf.
sp.p: I that he did Ifaith, he out-shind 'em all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Doost thou stand there and see vs all weepe, and not once shed a teare for thy fathers death? oh thou vngracious sonne and heyre thou:

sp.speaker: Edm,
sp.p: Troth Mother I should not weepe I'me sure; I am past a childe I hope, to make all my old Schoole fellowes laughe at me; I should bee mockt, so I should; Pray let one of my Sisters weepe for mee, Ile laughe as much for her another time?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Oh thou past-Grace thou, out of my sight, thou gracelesse impe, thou grieuest mee more then the death of thy Father? oh thou stubborne onely sonne? hadst thou such an honest man to thy Father— that would deceaue all the world to get riches for thee, and canst thou not afforde a little sa't water? he that so wisely did quite ouer-throw the right heyre of those lands, which now you respect not vp euery morning betwixt foure and fiue so duely at Westminster Hall euery Tearme-Time, with all his Cardes and writings, for thee thou wicked Absolon— oh deare husband!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Weep? quotha? I protest I am glad hee's Churched? for now hee's gone I shall spend in quiet?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Deere mother; pray cease, halfe your Teares suffize,
Tis time for you to take truce with youre eyes,
Let me weepe now?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Oh such a deere knight! such a sweete husband haue I lost, haue I lost?— if Blessed bee the coarse the raine raynes vpon, he had it powring downe?

sp.speaker: Syr Godf,
sp.p: Sister? be of good cheere, wee are all mortall our selues, I come vppon you freshly, I neare speake without comfort, heere me what I shall say;— my brother ha's left you wellthy, y'are rich.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Syr Godf.
sp.p: I say y'ar rich? you are also faire.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p:
Goe too y'are faire you cannot smother it, beauty will come to light; nor are your yeares so farre enterd with you; but that you will bee sought after; and may very well answere another husband; the world is full of fine Gallants,
choyse enow Sister,— for what should wee doe with all our Knights I pray? but to marry riche widdowes, wealthy Cittizens widdowes; lusty faire-browd Ladies; go too, bee of good comfort I say leaue snobbing and weeping— yet my Brother was a kinde hearted man— I would not haue the Elfe see mee now?— come pluck vp a womans heart— here stands your Daughters, who be well estated, and at maturity will also bee enquir'd after with good husbands, so all these teares shall bee soone dryed vp and a better world then euer— what? Woman? you must not weepe still? hee's dead hee's buried— yet I cannot chuse but weepe for him!

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.l: Marry againe! no! let me be buried quick then!
And that same part of Quire whereon I tread
To such intent, O may it be my graue;
And that the Priest may turne his wedding praiers,
Een with a breath, to all dust and ashes;
sp.p: Oh, out of a million of millions, I should nere finde such a husband, hee was vnmatchable,— vnmatchable? nothing was to hot, nor to deere for mee, I could not speake of that one thing that I had not, beside I had keyes of all, kept all, receiu'd all, had money in my purse, spent what I would, went abroad when I would, came home when I would, and did all what I would? Oh— my sweete husband; I shall neuer haue the like?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf
sp.p: Sister? nere say so; hee was an honest brother of mine, and so, and you may light vpon one as honest againe, or one, as honest againe may light vpon you, that's the properer phrase indeed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Neuer? oh if you loue me vrge it not,
Oh may I be the by-word of the world,
The common talke at Table in the mouth
Of euery Groome and Wayter, if e're more
I entertaine the carnall suite of Man?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I must kneele downe for fashion too?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.l: And I, whom neuer man as yet hath scalde
Ee'n in this depth of generall sorrow, vowe
Neuer to marry, to sustaine such losse
As a deere husband seemes to be, once dead?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I lou'd my father well too; but to say,
Nay now, I would not marry for his death?
Sure I should speake false Lattin; should I not?
Ide as soone vow neuer to come in Bed.
Tut? Women must liue by th' quick, and not by th' dead.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Deare Copie of my husband, oh let me kisse thee:
How like him is their Model? their briefe Picture
Quickens my teares: my sorrowes are renew'd
At their fresh sight?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sister—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Away,
All honesty with him is turn'd to clay,
Oh my sweete husband, oh—

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: My deere father?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Here's a puling indeede! I thinke my Mother weepes for all the women that euer buried husbands: for if from time to time all the Widdowers teares in England had beene bottled vp, I do not thinke all would haue fild a three-halfe-penny Bottle; Alasse a small matter bucks a hand-kercher,— and somtimes the spittle stands to nie Saint Thomas a Watrings; well, I can mourne in good sober sort as well as another? but where I spend one teare for a dead Father, I could giue twenty kisses for a quick husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Well, go thy waies old Sir Godfrey, and thou maist be proud on't, thou hast a kinde louing sister-in-lawe; how constant? how passionate? how ful of Aprill the poore soules eyes are; well, I would my Brother knew on't, he should then know what a kinde wife hee had left behinde him; truth and twere not for shame that the Neighbours at th next garden should heare me, betweene ioye and griefe, I should e'en cry out-right!

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.p:
So, a faire riddance, my father's layde in dust, his Coffin and he is like a whole-meate-pye, and the wormes will cut him vp shortlie; farewell old Dad, farewe'l. Ile be curb'd in no more, I perceiue a sonne and heire may quickly be made
a foole and he will be one, but Ile take another order;— Now she would haue me weepe for him for-sooth, and why? because he cozn'd the right heire beeing a foole, and bestow'd those Lands vpon me his eldest Son; and therefore I must weepe for him ha, ha; Why al the world knowes as long as twas his pleasure to get me, twas his duety to get for me: I know the law in that point no Atturney can gull me; Well, my Vncle is an olde Asse, and an admirable Cockscombe, Ile rule the Roast my selfe, Ile be kept vnder no more, I know what I may do well inough by my Fathers Copy: the Lawe's in mine owne hands now: nay now I know my strength, Ile be strong inough for my Mother I warrant you?

div.stage: Enter George Py-bord a scholler and a Cittizen and vnto him an old soulder, Peter Skirmish.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: What's to be done now? old Lad of War; thou that wert wont to be as hot as a turn-spit, as nimble as a fencer, & as lowzy as a schoole-maister; now thou art put to silence like a Sectarie?— war sitts now like a Iustice of peace, and does nothing, where be your Muskets, Caleiuers and Hotshots? in Long-lane, at Pawne, at Pawne;— Now keies, are your onely Guns, Key-guns, Key-guns, & Bawdes the Gunners,— who are your centinells in peace, and stand ready charg'd to giue warning; with hems, hums, & pockey-coffs; only your Chambers are licenc'st to play vpon you, and Drabs enow to giue fire to 'em.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell, but I am sure it goes wrong with me, for since the cessure of the wars, I haue spent aboue a hundred crownes out a purse: I haue beene a souldier any time this forty yeares, and now I perceiue an olde souldier, and an olde Courtier haue both one destinie, and in the end turne both into hob-nayles.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Prety mistery for a begger, for indeed a hob-naile is the true embleme of a beggers shoo-soale;

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p:
I will not say but that warre is a bloud-sucker, and so; but in my conscience, (as there is no souldier but has a peice of one, tho it bee full of holes like a shot Antient, no matter, twill serue to sweare by) in my conscience, I thinke some kinde of
Peace, ha's more hidden oppressions, and violent heady sinnes, (tho looking of a gentle nature) then a profest warre.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Troth, and for mine owne part, I am a poore Gentleman, & a Scholler, I haue beene matriculated in the Vniuersitie, wore out sixe Gownes there, seene some fooles, and some Schollers, some of the Citty, and some of the Countrie, kept order, went bare-headed ouer the Quadrangle, eate my Commons with a good stomacke, and Battled with Discretion; at last, hauing done many slights and trickes to maintaine my witte in vse (as my braine would neuer endure mee to bee idle,) I was expeld the Vniuersitie, onely for stealing a Cheese out of Iesus Colledge.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Oh! there was one Welshman (God forgiue him) pursued it hard; and neuer left, till I turnde my staffe toward London, where when I came, all my friends were pitt-hold, gone to Graues, (as indeed there was but a few left before) then was I turnde to my wittes, to shift in the world, to towre among Sonnes and Heyres, and Fooles, and Gulls, and Ladyes eldest Sonnes, to worke vpon nothing, to feede out of Flint, and euer since has my belly beene much beholding to my braine: But now to returne to you old Skirmish. I say as you say, and for my part wish a Turbulency in the world, for I haue nothing to loose but my wittes, and I thinke they are as mad as they will be: and to strengthen your Argument the more, I say an honest warre, is better then a bawdy peace: as touching my profession; The multiplicitie of Schollers, hatcht, and nourisht, in the idle Calmes of peace, makes 'em like Fishes one deuoure another; and the communitie of Learning ha's so plaide vpon affections, and thereby almost Religion is come about to Phantasie, and discredited by being too much spoken off— in so many & meane mouths, I my selfe being a Scholler and a Graduate, haue no other comfort by my learning, but the Affliction of my words, to know how Scholler-like to name what I want, & can call my selfe a Begger both in Greeke and Lattin, and therfore not to cogg with Peace, Ile not be afraide to say, 'tis a great Breeder, but a barren Nourisher: a great-getter of Children, which must either be Theeues or Rich-men, Knaues or Beggers.

sp.speaker: Skirmish.
sp.p: Well, would I had beene borne a Knaue then, when I was borne a Begger, for if the truth were knowne, I thinke I was begot when my Father had neuer a penny in his purse.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, faint not old Skirmish, let this warrant thee, Facilis Descensus Auerni, 'tis an easie iourney to a Knaue, thou maist bee a Knaue when thou wilt; and Peace is a good Madam to all other professions, and an arrant Drabbe to vs, let vs handle her accordingly, and by our wittes thriue in despight of her; for since the lawe liues by quarrells, the Courtier by smooth God-morrowes, and euery profession makes it selfe greater by imperfections, why not wee then by shiftes, wiles, and forgeries? and seeing our braines are our onely Patrimonies, let's spend with iudgment, not like a desperate sonne and heire, but like a sober and discreete Templer,— one that will neuer marche beyond the bounds of his allowance, and for our thriuing meanes, thus, I my selfe will put on the Deceit of a Fortune-teller, a Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Skirm.
sp.p: Very proper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And you of a figure-caster, or a Coniurer.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: A Coniurer.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Let me alone, Ile instruct you, and teach you to deceiue all eyes, but the Diuels.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Oh I, for I would not deceiue him and I could choose, of all others.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Feare not I warrant you; and so by those meanes wee shall helpe one another to Patients, as the condition of the age affoords creatures enow for cunning to worke vpon.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Oh wondrous new fooles and fresh Asses.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Oh, fit, fit, excellent.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: What in the name of Coniuring?

sp.speaker: Pye-boord.
sp.p: My memorie greetes mee happily with an admirable subiect to graze vpon. The Lady-Widdow, who of late I sawe weeping in her Garden for the death of her Husband, sure she'as but a watrish soule, and halfe on't by this time is dropt out of her Eies: deuice well managde may doe good vppon her: it stands firme, my first practise shall bee there?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: You haue my voyce George?

sp.speaker: Pye-boord.
sp.p: Sh'as a gray Gall to her Brother, a foole to her onely sonne, and an Ape to her yongest Daughter;— I ouer-heard 'em seuerally, and from their words Ile deriue my deuice; and thou old Peter Skirmish shall be my second in all slights.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Nere doubt mee George Pye-boord.— onely you must teach me to coniure.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Idle, pinioned, & with a guarde of Officers passeth ouer the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Push, Ile perfect thee, Peter:
How now? what's hee?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.l: Oh George! this sight kils me,
Tis my sworne Brother, Captaine Idle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captaine Idle.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Apprehended for some fellonious act or other, hee has started out, h'as made a Night on't, lackt siluer; I cannot but commend his resolution, he would not pawne his Buffe-Ierkin, I would eyther some of vs were employde, or might pitch our Tents at Vsurers doores, to kill the slaues as they peepe out at the Wicket.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Indeed those are our ancient Enimies; they keepe our money in their hands, and make vs to bee hangd for robbing of 'em, but come letts follow after to the Prison, and know the Nature of his offence, and what we can steed him in, hee shall be sure of; and Ile vphold it still, that a charitable Knaue, is better then a soothing Puritaine.

div.stage: Enter at one doore Corporall Oth, a Vaine-glorious fellow, and at the other, three of the Widdow Puritaines Seruingmen, Nicholas Saint-Tantlings, Simon Saint-Mary-Oueries, and Frailtie in black scuruie mourning coates, and Bookes at their Girdles, as comming from Church. They meete.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What Corporall Oth? I am sorry we haue met with you next our hearts; you are the man that we are forbidden to keepe company withall, wee must not sweare I can tell you, and you haue the name for swearing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I, Corporall Oth, I would you would do so much as forsake vs sir, we cannot abide you, wee must not be seene in your company.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: There is none of vs I can tell you, but shall be soundly whipt for swearing.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Why how now? we three? Puritanicall Scrape-shoes, Flesh a good Fridayes? a hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Why Nicholas Saint-Tantlings, Simon Saint Mary Oueries, ha's the De'ele possest you, that you sweare no better, you halfe-Christned Katomites, you vngod-motherd Varlets, do's the first lesson teach you to bee proud, and the second to bee Cocks-combes; proud Cocks-combes? not once to doe dutie to a man of Marke.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: A man of Marke, quatha, I doe not thinke he can shew a Beggers Noble.

sp.speaker: Corpo.
sp.p: A Corporall, a Commander, one of spirit; that is able to blowe you vp all drye with your Bookes at your Girdles.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Wee are not taught to beleeue that sir, for we know the breath of man is weake?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Foh, you lie Nicholas; for here's one strong inough; blowe vs vp quotha! hee may well blow me aboue twelue-score off an him? I warrant if the winde stood right, a man might smell him from the top of Newgate, to the Leades of Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou Hollow-Booke of Waxe-candle.

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.p: I, you may say what you will, so you sweare not.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I sweare by the—

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Corporall Oth; for if you sweare once, wee shall all fall downe in a sowne presently.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I must and will sweare: you quiuering Cocks-combes, my Captaine is imprisoned, and by Uulcans Lether Cod-piece point—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O Simon, what an oth was there.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: If hee should chance to breake it, the poore mans Breeches would fall downe about his heeles, for Venus allowes him but one point to his hose?

sp.speaker: Corpor.
sp.p: With these my Bullye-Feete, I will thumpe ope the Prison doores, and braine the Keeper with the begging Boxe, but Ile set my honest sweete Captaine Idle at libertie.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: How, Captaine Ydle, my olde Aunts sonne, my deere Kinsman in Capadochio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I, thou Church-peeling, thou Holy-paring, religious outside thou? if thou hadst any grace in thee, thou would'st visit him, releiue him, sweare to get him out?

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.p: Assure you Corporall indeed-la, tis the first time I heard on't,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why do 't now then, Marmaset? bring forth thy yearly-wages, let not a Commander perish!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: But, if hee bee one of the wicked, hee shall perish.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Well Corporall, Ile e'en along with you, to visit my Kinsman, if I can do him any good, I will,— but I haue nothing for him, Simon Saint Mary Oueris and Fraylty, pray make a lie for me to the Knight my Maister, old Sir Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A lie? may you lie then?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O I, we may lie, but me must not sweare.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True, wee may lie with our Neighbors wife, but wee must not sweare we did so;

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh, an excellent Tag of religion?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh Simon, I haue thought vpon a sound excuse, it will go currant, say that I am gon to a Fast;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: To a Fast, very good?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I, to a Fast say, with Maister Ful-bellie the Minister.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Maister Ful-bellie? an honest man: he feedes the flock well, for he's an excellent feeder?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O I, I haue seene him eate vp a whole Pigge, and afterward falls to the pettitoes?

div.stage: Enter Captaine Ydle at one dore, and old souldier at the other.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray turne the key.

sp.speaker: Sker.
sp.p: Turne the key I pray?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who should those be, I almost know their voyces? O my friends?
Ya're welcome to a smelling Roome here? you newly tooke leaue of the ayre ist not a strange sauour?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: 'As all prisons haue, smells of sundry wretches;
Who tho departed, leaue their sents behind 'em,
By God Captaine, I am sincerely sory for thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By my troth George I thanke thee; but pish,— what must be, must bee.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Captaine, what doe you lie in for? ist great? what's your offence?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faith, my offence is ordinarie,— common? A Hie-waye, and I feare mee my penaltie will be ordinarie and common too, a halter.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Nay prophecy not so ill, it shall go heard'
But Ile shift for thy life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whether I liue or die, thou art an honest George Ile tell you— siluer flou'd not with mee, as it had done, (for now the tide runnes to Bawdes and flatterers) I had a start out, and by chaunce set vpon a fat steward, thinking his purse had beene as pursey as his bodie; and the slaue had about him but the poore purchase of tenne groates: notwithstanding beeing descryed, pursued, and taken, I know the Law is so grim: in respect of many desprate-vnsetled souldiours, that I feare mee I shall daunce after their pipe for't.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I am twice sory for you Captaine: first that your purchase was so small, and now that your danger is so great.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Push, the worst is but death,— ha you a pipe of Tobacco about you?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I thinke, I haue there abouts about me!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Her's a cleane Gentleman too, to receiue?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Well, I must cast about, some happy slight,
Worke braine, that euer didst thy Maister right?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Keeper? let the key be turn'dl

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I, I pray Maister keeper giues a cast of your office? within.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How now more Visitants?— what Corporall Oth?

sp.speaker: Pie. Skir.
sp.p: Corporal?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In prison honest Captaine? this must not be?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How do you Captaine Kinsman?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Good Cocks-combe? what makes that pure— starch'd foole here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You see Kinsman I am som-what bould to call in, and see how you do, I heard you were safe inough, and I was very glad on't that it was no worse;

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This is a double torture now,— this foole by'th booke
Do's vexe me more then my imprisonment?
What meant you Corporall to hooke him hither?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Who he? he shall releiue thee, and supply thee,
Ile make him doo't;

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fie, what vaine breath you spend! hee supply? Ile sooner expect mercy from a Vsurer when my bonds forfetted, sooner kindnesse from a Lawier when my mony's spent: nay sooner charity from the deuill, then good from a Puritaine? Ile looke for releife from him, when Lucifer is restor'd to his bloud, and in Heauen againe!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I warrant my Kinsman's talking of me, for my left eare burnes most tyrannically?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Captaine Ydle? what's he there? hee lookes; like a Monkey vpward; and a Crane downe-ward.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pshaw; a foolish Cozen of mine; I must thanke God for him.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why the better subiect to worke a scape vpon; thou shalt e'en change clothes with him, and leaue him here, and so;

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Push, I publish't him e'en now to my Corporall, hee will be damn'd, ere hee do me so much good; why I know a more proper, a more handsome deuice then that, if the slaue would be sociable— now goodman Fleere-face?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, my Cozen begins to speake to me now, I shall bee acquainted with him againe I hope,

sp.speaker: Skirmish.
sp.p: Looke what ridiculous Raptures take hold of his wrinckles,

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Then what say you to this deuice, a happy one Captaine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Speake lowe George; Prison Rattes haue wider eares then those in Malt-lofts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Cozen, if it lay in my power, as they say?— to— do;

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Twould do me an exceeding pleasure indeed that, but nere talke forder on't, the foole will be hang'd, ere he do't.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pax, Ile thump 'em to't.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why doe but trie the Fopster, and breake it to him bluntly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And so my disgrace will dwell in his Iawes, and the slaue slauer out our purpose to his Maister, for would I were but as sure on't as I am sure he will deny to do't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I would bee heartily glad Cozen, if any of my friendships, as they say, might— stand, ah,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why, you see he offers his friend-ship foolishly to you alreadie?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I, that's the hell on't, I would hee would offer it wisely?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Verily, and indeed la, Couzen?—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I haue tooke note of thy fleers a good while, if thou art minded to do mee good? as thou gapst vpon me comfortably, and giu'st me charitable faces? which indeede is but a fashion in you all that are Puritaines? wilt soone at night steale me thy Maisters chaine?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, I shall sowne!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Corporal, he starts already!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I know it to be worth three hundred Crownes, & with the halfe of that, I can buy my life at a Brokers, at second hand, which now lies in pawne to'th Lawe, if this thou refuse to do, being easie and nothing dangerous, in that thou art held in good opinion of thy Maister, why tis a palpable Argument thou holdst my life at no price, and these thy broken & vnioynted offers, are but only created in thy lip, now borne, and now buried, foolish breath onlie? what; woult do't? shall I looke for happinesse in thy answere?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Steale my Maisters chane quo'the? no, it shal nere bee sayd that Nicholas Saint Tantlings committed Bird-lime!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, I told you as much; did I not; tho he be a Puritaine yet he will be a true man?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Couzen? you know tis written, thou shalt not steale?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why, and foole, thou shalt loue thy Neighbour, and helpe him in extremities?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Masse I thinke it bee indeede, in what Chapter's that Couzen?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why in the first of Charity, the 2. verse.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: The first of Charity, quotha tha, that's a good iest, there's no such Chapter in my booke!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, I knew twas torne out of thy Booke, & that makes so little in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Come, let me tell you, ya're too vnkinde a Kinsman yfaith; the Captaine louing you so deerely, I, like the Pomwater of his eye, and you to be so vncomfortable, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pray do not wish me to bee hangd, any thing else that I can do, had it beene to rob, I would ha don't, but I must not steale, that's the word the literall, thou shalt not steale, and would you wish me to steale then?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: No faith, that were to much, to speake truth: why woult thou nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That I will?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why ynough bullie; hee shall bee content with that, or he shall ha none; let mee alone with him now! Captaine, I ha dealt with your Kins-man in a Corner; a good, kind-naturde fellow, mee thinkes: goe too, you shall not haue all your owne asking, you shall bate somewhat on't he is not contented absolutely as you would say to steale the chaine from him,— but to do you a pleasure he will nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I, that I will, Couzen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well seeing he will doe no more, as far as I see I must bee contented with that.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here's no notable gullery?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay Ile come neerer to you Gentleman? because weele haue onely but a helpe and a mirth on't, the knight shall not loose his chaine neither, but be only laide out of the way some one or two daies?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I, that would be good indeed? Kinsman?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
For I haue a farder reach to profit vs better by the missing on't onelie, then if wee had it out-right, as my discourse shall make it knowne too you?— when thou hast the chaine, do but
conuay it out at back-dore into the Garden, and there hang it close in the Rosemary banck, but for a small season; and by that harmlesse deuise, I know how to winde Captaine Ydle, out of prison, the Knight thy Maister shall get his pardon and release him, & he satisfie thy Maister with his own chaine & wondrous thankes on both hands.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That were rare indeed la: pray let me know how?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay tis very necessary thou shouldst know, because thou must be imploide as an Actor?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: An Actor? O no, that's a Plaier? and our Parson railes againe Plaiers mightily I can tell you, because they brought him drunck vpp'oth Stage once,— as hee will bee horribly druncke.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Masse I cannot blame him then, poore Church-spout?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why as an Intermedler then?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I that, that.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Giue me Audience then? when the old Knight thy Maister has radge his fill for the losse of the chaine, tell him thou hast a Kinsman in prison, of such exquisit Art, that the diuill himselfe is french Lackey to him, and runnes bare-headed by his horse-belly (when hee has one) whome hee will cause with most Yrish Dexterity to fetch his chaine, tho twere hid vnder a mine of sea-cole, and nere make Spade or Pickaxe his instruments, tell him but this with farder instructions thou shalt receiue from mee, and thou shoust thy selfe a Kinsman indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A dainty Bullie.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: An honest— Booke-keeper.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And my three times thrice hunnie Couzen.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Nay grace of God Ile robbe him on't suddainlie? and hang it in the Rosemary banck, but I beare that minde Couzen I would not steale any thing mee thinkes for mine owne Father.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: He beares a good minde in that Captaine!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why well sayde, he begins to be an honest fellow faith.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In troth he does.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You see Couzen, I am willing to do you any kindnesse, alwaies sauing my selfe harmelesse?

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.p: Why I thanke thee, fare thee well, I shall requite it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Twill bee good for thee Captaine, that thou hast such an egregious Asse to thy Coozen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I, is hee not a fine foole Corporall?
But George thou talkst of Art and Coniuring,
How shall that bee?

sp.speaker: Peb.
sp.l: Puh, bee't not in your care,
Leaue that to me and my directions;
Well Captaine doubt not thy deliuerie now,
E'en with the vantage man, to gaine by prison,
As my thoughts prompt me: hold on braine and plot,
I ayme at many cunning far euents,
All which I doubt not but to hit at length,
Ile to the Widdow with a quaint assault,
Captaine be merry.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who I? Kerrie merry Buffe-Ierkin?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Oh, I am happy in more slights, and one will knit strong in another— Corporall Oth?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Hoh Bully?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And thou old Peter Skirmish, I haue a necessary taske for you both.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay't vpon George Pye-boord.

sp.speaker: Corp
sp.p: What ere it bee, weele manage it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I would haue you two maintaine a quarrell before the
Lady Widdowes doore, and drawe your swords i'th edge of the
Euening: clash a little, clash, clash.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.l: Fuh.
Let vs alone to make our Blades ring noone,
Tho it be after Supper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Know you can;
sp.p:
And out of that false fire, I doubt not but to raise strange beleefe— and Captaine to countenance my deuice the better, and grace my words to the Widdow, I haue a good plaine Sattin sute, that I had of a yong Reueller t'other night, for words passe not regarded now a dayes vnlesse they come from a good suite of cloaths, which the Fates and my wittes haue bestowed vpon me. Well Captaine Idle, if I did not highly loue thee, I would
nere bee seene within twelue score of a prison, for I protest at this instant, I walke in great danger of small debts. owe I money to seuerall Hostisses, and you know such Jills will quickly be vpon a mans Iack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: True George?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fare thee well Captaine. Come Corporall and Ancient? thou shalt heare more newes next time we greete thee?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: More newes? I; by you Beare at Bridge-Foote in heauen shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Inough: my friends farewell,
This prison shewes as if Ghosts did part in Hell.

div.stage: Enter Moll yongest Daughter to the Widdow: alone.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Not Marry: forsweare Marriage? why all women know 'tis as honorable a thing as to lye with a man; and I to spight my Sisters vowe the more, haue entertainde a suter already, a fine gallant Knight of the last Fether, hee sayes he will Coach mee too, and well appoint mee, allow mee money to Dice with-all, and many such pleasing protestations hee sticks vpon my lips; indeed his short-winded Father ith' Countrie is wondrous wealthy, a most abhominable Farmer, and therefore hee may doote in time: troth Ile venture vpon him; women are not without wayes enow to helpe them-selues, if he proue wise and good as his word, why I shall loue him, and vse him kindly: and if hee prooue an Asse, why in a quarter of an houres warning I can transforme him into an Oxe;— there comes in my Reliefe agen.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O Mistresse Moll, Mistresse Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How now? what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: The Knight your suter, sir Iohn Penny-Dub.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Penny-Dub? where? where?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Hee's walking in the Gallerie.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Ha's my Mother seene him yet.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no, shee's— spitting in the Kitchin.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Direct him hether softly, good Frailtie,— Ile meete him halfe way.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: That's iust like running a Tilt; but I hope heele breake nothing this time.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: 'Tis happinesse my Mother saw him not:
O welcome good Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Penny-dub.
sp.p: I thanke you faith,— Nay you must stand mee, till I kisse you: 'tis the fashion euery where I-faith, and I came from Court enow?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay the Fates forsend that I should anger the fashion?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Then not forgetting the sweete of new ceremonies, I first fall back, then recouering my selfe; make my honour to your lip thus: and then accost it.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Trust me, very pritty, and mouing, y'are worthy on't sir,—
O my Mother, my Mother, now shee's here,
Weele steale into the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay Sister, let Reason rule you, doe not play the foole, stand not in your owne light, you haue wealthy offers, large tendrings, doe not with-stand your good fortune: who comes a wooing to you I pray? no small foole, a rich Knight ath Citty, Sir Oliuer Muck-hill, no small foole I can tell you: and furthermore as I heard late by your Maide-seruants, (as your Maide-seruants will say to mee any thing I thanke 'em) both your Daughters are not without Suters, I, and worthy ones too? one a Briske Courtier, Sir Andrew Tip-staffe; suter a farre off to your eldest Daughter, and the third a huge-welthie Farmers sonne, a fine young Countrie Knight, they call him Sir Iohn Penny-Dab, a good name marry, hee may haue it coynde when hee lackes money: what blessings are these Sister?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Tempt me not Satan.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Satan? doe I looke like Satan? I hope the Deuill's not so old as I, I tro.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You wound my sences Brother, when you name,
A suter to me,— oh I cannot abide it,
I take in poison, when I heare one nam'd,
How now Simon? where's my sonne Edmund?

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: verily Madame, hee is at vaine Exercise, dripping in the Tennis-court.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: At Tennis-court? oh, now his father's gon, I shall haue no rule with him; oh wicked Edmond, I might well compare this with the Prophecie in the Chronicle, tho farre inferior, as Harry of Monmouth woone all, and Harry of Windsor lost all, so Edmund of Bristow that was the Father, got all, and Edmond of London that's his sonne now, will spend all?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Peace Sister, weele haue hem reformd, there's hope on him yet, tho it be but a little.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Forsooth Madam? there are two or three Archers at doore, would very gladly speake with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Archers?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Your husbands Fletcher I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Oh,
Let them come neere, they bring home things of his,
Troth I should ha forgot 'em, how now?
Villaine, which be those Archers?

div.stage: Enter the suters Sir Andrew Tipstaffe, Sir Oliuer Much-hill, and Penny-dub.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Who do you not see 'em before you, are not these Archers, what do you call 'em Shooters: Shooters and Archers are all one I hope.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Out ignorant slaue.

sp.speaker: Muck
sp.l: Nay pray be patient Lady,
We come in way of honorable loue.

sp.speaker: Tipst. Penny.
sp.p: Wee doe.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: To you.

sp.speaker: Tipst. Penny.
sp.p: And to your Daughters?

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p:
O why will you offer mee this Gentlemen? indeed I will not looke vppon you; when the Teares are scarce out of mine Eyes, not yet washt off from my Cheekes, and my deere husbands body scarse so colde as the Coffin, what reason haue you to offer it? I am not like some of your Widdowes that will burie one in the Euening, and bee sure to another ere morning? pray away, pray, take your answeres good
Knights, and you bee sweete Knights, I haue vow'd neuer to marry;— and so haue my daughters too!

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: I two of you haue, but the thirds a good wench!

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Lady, a shrewde answere marry; the best is, tis but the first, and hee's a blunt wooer, that will leaue for one sharpe answere.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Where bee your daughters Lady, I hope theile giue vs better encouragements?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Indeed theyle answere you so, tak't a my word theile giue you the very same answere Verbatim truly la;

sp.speaker: Penny
sp.p: Mum: Molls a good wench still, I know what shee'le doo?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Well, Lady, for this time weele take our leaues, hoping for better comfort.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O neuer, neuer? and I liue these thousand yeares; and you bee good Knights doe not hope; twill bee all Vaine, Vayne,— looke you, put off all yours suites, and you come to me againe.

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: Put off all their suites qua tha? I, that's the best wooing of a Widdow indeed, when a man's Nonsuted, that is, when he's a bed with her.

div.stage: Going out, Muckhill and sir Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sir Godfrey? here's twenty Angells more worke hard for me; there's life int yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Feare not Sir Oliuer Muckhill, Ile stick close for you, leaue all with me.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: By your leaue Ladie Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What another suiter now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A suiter no I protest Ladie? if you'de giue me your selfe
Ide not be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, then you're the better welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay Heauen blesse mee from a Widdow, vnlesse I were sure to bury her speedily!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good bluntnesse: well your businesse sir?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Very needfull; if you were in priuate once?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Needfull? brother pray leaue vs; and you sir?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p:
I should laugh now, if this blunt fellow should put 'em
all beside the stirrop, and vault into the saddle himselfe, I haue seene as mad a trick.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Now Sir?— here's none but we— Daughters forbeare.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: O no, pray let 'em stay, for what I haue to speake importeth equally to them as to you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then you may stay.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I pray bestow on me a serious eare,
For what I speake is full of weight and feare?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Feare?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I ift passe vnregarded, and vneffected,
Else peace and ioy:— I pray Attention?
sp.p: Widdowe? I haue beene a meere stranger for these parts that you liue in, nor did I euer know the Husband of you, and Father of them, but I truly know by certaine spirituall Intelligence, that he is in Purgatorie?

sp.speaker: Wed.
sp.p: Purgatorie? tuh; that word deserues to bee spit vpon; I wonder that a man of sober toung as you seeme to be, should haue the folly to beleeue there's such a place.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Well Lady, in cold bloud I speake it, I assure you that there is a Purgatory, in which place I know your husband to recide and wherein he is like to remaine, till the dissolution of the world, till the last generall Bon-fire: when all the earth shall melt into nothing, and the Seas scalde their finnie labourers: so long is his abidance, vnlesse you alter the propertie of your purpose, together with each of your Daughters theirs, that is, the purpose of single life in your selfe and your eldest Daughter, and the speedie determination of marriage in your youngest.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How knowes hee that, what, h'as some Deuill told him?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Strange he should know our thoughts:—
Why but Daughter haue you purposede speedy Marriage?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: You see she tels you I, for shee sayes nothing. Nay giue me credit as you please, I am a stranger to you, and yet you see I know your determinations, which must come to mee Metaphisically, and by a super-naturall intelligence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This puts Amazement on me?

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Know our seacrets.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Ide thought to steale a marriage, would his tongue
Had dropt out when he blabt it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But sir, my husband, was too honest a dealing man to be now in any purgatories—

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: O Do not loade your conscience with vntruths,
Tis but meere folly now to guild hem ore:
That has past but for Copper; Praises here,
Cannot vnbinde him there? confesse but truth,
I know he got his wealth with a hard gripe:
Oh hardly, hardly?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is most strange of all, how knowes he that?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: He would eate fooles and ignorant heires cleane vp;
And had his drinck, from many a poore mans browe,
E'en as their labour brewde it?
He would scrape ritches to him most vniustly;
The very durt betweene his nailes was Il-got:
And not his owne,— oh
sp.p: I groane to speake on't, the though't makes me shudder?— shudder?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It quakes me too, now I thinke on't— sir, I am much grieu'd, that you a stranger should so deeply wrong my dead husband!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Oh?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A man that would keepe Church so duly; rise early, before his seruants, and e'en for Religious hast, go vngarterd, vnbuttend, nay sir Reuerence vntrust, to Morning Prayer?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Oh vff;

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Dine quickly vpon hie-dayes, and when I had great guesse, would e'en shame me and rize from the Table, to get a good seate at an after-noone Sermon?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: There's the diuill, there's the diuill, true, hee thought it Sanctity ynough, if he had kild a man, so tad beene done in a Pue, or vndon his Neighour, so ta'd beene nere ynough to'th Preacher, Oh;— a Sermon's a fine short cloake of an houre long, and wil hide the vpper-part of a dissembler,— Church, I, he seemed al Church, & his conscience was as hard as the Pulpit!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I can no more endure this.

sp.speaker: Pie,
sp.l: Nor I widdow
Endure to flatter.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is this all your businesse with me?

sp.speaker: Pie,
sp.l: No, Lady, tis but the induction too'te,
You may beleiue my straines, I strike all true?
sp.p: And if your conscience would leap vp to your tongue, your selfe would affirme it, and that you shall perceiue I knowe of things to come; as well as I doe of what is present, a Brother of your husbands shall shortly haue a losse!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A losse, marry heauen for-fend, Sir Godfrey, my brother!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay keepe in your wonders, till I haue told you the fortunes of you all; which are more fearefull, if not happily preuented— for your part & your daughters, if there be not once this day some bloud-shed before your dore, wheerof the humaine creature dies? two of you the elder shall run mad?

sp.speaker: Mother and Franck.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: That's not I yet!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: And with most impudent prostitution show your naked bodies to the veiw of all beholders!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Our naked bodies? fie for shame:

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Attend mee: and your yonger daughter bee strocken dumbe?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumbe? out alasse: tis the worst paine of all for a Woman, Ide rather bee madde, or runne naked, or any thing: dumbe?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Giue eare? ere the euening fall vpon, Hill Bogge, and Meadow, this my speech shal haue past probation, and then shal I be belieued accordingly.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p: If this bee true, wee are all sham'de, all vndon?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumbe? Ile speake as much as euer I can possible before euening?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
But if it so come to passe (as for your faire sakes I wish it may) that this presage of your strange fortunes be preuented by that accident of death & bloud-shedding which I before told you off: take heed vpon your liues; that two of you which haue vow'd neuer to marry, seeke you out husbands with all present speede
and you the third that haue such a desire to out-strip chastitie, looke you meddle not with a husband.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A double torment.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: The breach of this keepes your father in Purgatorie, and the punishments that shall follow you in this world, would with horror kill the Eare should heare 'em related.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry? why I vowd neuer to marry.

sp.speaker: Franke.
sp.p: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I vowde neuer to be such an Asse, but to marry. what a crosse Fortune's this?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Ladies, tho I bee a Fortune-teller, I cannot better Fortunes, you haue 'em from me as they are reueald to me: I would they were to your tempers, and fellowes with your blouds, that's all the bitternesse I would you.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p: Oh 'tis a iust vengeance, for my husbands hard purchases.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I wish you to be-thinke your selues, and leau'em.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile to Sir Godfrey my Brother, and acquaint him with these fearefull presages.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: For Mother they portend losses to him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Oh I, they doe, they doe,
If any happy issue crowne thy words,
I will reward thy cunning.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: 'Tis enough Lady,
I wish no higher.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Dumbe, and not marry, worse,
Neither to speake, nor kisse, a double curse?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p:
So all this comes well about yet, I play the Fortune-teller, as well as if I had had a Witch to my Grannam: for by good happinesse, being in my Hostisses Garden, which neighbours the Orchard of the Widdow, I laid the hole of mine eare to a hole in the wall, and heard 'em make these vowes, & speake those words vpon which I wrought these aduantages; and to encourage my forgerie the more, I may now perceiue in 'em a naturall simplicitie which will easily swallow an abuse, if any couering be ouer it: and to confirme my former presage to the Widdow, I haue aduizde old Peter Skirmish the Souldier, to hurt Corporall Oth vpon the Leg, and in that hurry Ile rush amongst
'em, and in stead of giuing the Corporal some Cordiall to comfort him, Ile power into his mouth a potion of a sleepy Nature, to make him seeme as dead; for the which the old souldier beeing apprehended, and ready to bee borne to execution, Ile step in, & take vpon me the cure of the dead man, vpon paine of dying the condemneds death: the Corporall will wake at his minute, when the sleepy force has wrought it selfe, and so shall I get my selfe into a most admired opinion, and vnder the pretext of that cunning, beguile as I see occasion: and if that foolish Nicholas Saint Tantlings keepe true time with the chaine, my plot wil be found; the Captaine deliuered, and my wits applauded among schollers and souldiers for euer.

div.stage: Enter Nicholas Saint Tantlings with the chaine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh I haue found an excellent aduantage to take away the chaine, my Maister put it off e'en now to say on a new Doublet, and I sneak't it away by little & little most Puritanically! wee shall haue good sport anon when ha's mist it, about my Cozen the Coniurer, the world shall see I'me an honest man of my word for now I'me going to hang it betweene Heauen & Earth among the Rosemary branches.

div.head: Actus 3.
div.stage: Enter Simon Saint Mary-Oueries and Frailty.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Sirrah Simon Saint? my Mistris sends away all her suiters and puts fleas in their their?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Frailty? she dos like an honest chast, and vertuous woman? for widdowes ought not to wallow in the puddle of iniquity.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yet Simon, many widdowes wil do't, what so comes on't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True Frailtie, their filthy flesh desires a Coniunction Copulatiue what strangers are within, Frailty?

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Ther's none Simon but Maister Pilfer the Tailer: he's aboue with Sir Godfreie praysing of a Doublet: and I must trudge anon to fetch Maister Suds the Barber!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.l: Maister Suds, a good man, he washes the sinns of the
Beard cleane.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: How now creatures? whats a clock.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Why do you take vs to be Iacke at'h Clock-house?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say agen to you what's a clocke?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly la, wee goe by the clocke of our conscience, all worldly Clockes we know goe false, and are set by drunken Sextons.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Then what's a clock in your conscience?— oh, I must breake off, here comes the corporall— hum, hum!— what's a clock?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: A clock? why past seuenteene.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Past seuenteene? nay ha's met with his match now, Corporall Oth will fit him.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Thou doost not bawke or baffle me, doost thou? I am a Souldier— past seuenteene.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I, thou art not angry with the figures art thou? I will prooue it vnto thee, 12. and 1. is thirteene I hope, 2. foureteene, 3. fifteene, 4 sixteene, and 5. seauenteene, then past seauenteene, I will take the Dyals part in a iust cause.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say 'tis but past fiue then.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Ile sweare 'tis past seauenteene then! doost thou not know numbers, canst thou not cast?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Cast? dost thou speake of my casting ith' street? Draw.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I, and in the Market place.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, clubs.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: I, I knew by their shuffling Clubs would be Trumpe; masse here's the Knaue, and hee can doe any good vppon 'em: Clubs, clubs, clubs?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O villaine, thou hast opend a vaine in my leg.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: How now, for shame, for shame, put vp, put vp.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By yon blew Welkin, 'twas out of my part George to bee hurt on the leg.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Oh peace now— I haue a Cordiall here to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Downe with 'em, downe with em, lay hands vpon the villaine.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay hands on me?.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Ile not be seene among em now.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ime hurt, and had more need haue Surgeons,
Lay hands vpon me then rough Officers.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Goe carry him to be drest then:
This mutinous Souldier shall along with me to prison.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: To prison, where's George.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: Away with hem.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: So,
All lights as I would wish, the amazd widdow,
Will plant me strongly now in her beleefe,
And wonder at the vertue of my words:
For the euent turnes those presages from em
Of being mad and dumbe, and begets ioy
Mingled with admiration: these emptie creatures,
Souldier and Corporall were but ordaind,
As instruments for me to worke vpon,
Now to my patient, here's his potion.

div.stage: Enter the Widdow with her two Daughters.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O wondrous happinesse, beyond our thoughts:
O luckie faire euent, I thinke our fortunes,
Were blest een in our Cradles: we are quitted
Of all those shamefull violent presages,
By this rash bleeding chance; goe Frailtie run, and know,
Whether he be yet liuing, or yet dead,
That here before my doore receiu'd his hurt.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Madam, hee was carryed to the superiour, but if he had no money when hee came there, I warrant hee's dead by this time.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Sure that man is a rare fortune-teller, neuer lookt vpon our hands, nor vpon any marke about vs, a wondrous fellow surelie.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am glad, I haue the vse of my tongue yet: tho of nothing else, I shall finde the way to marry too, I hope shortly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O where's my Brother sir Godfrey, I would hee were here, that I might relate to him how prophetically, the cunning Gentleman spoke in all things.

div.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey in a rage.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O my Chaine, my Chaine, I haue lost my Chaine, where be these Villains, Varlets?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh; has lost his Chaine.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My Chaine, my chaine.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p:
Brother bee patient, heare mee speake, you know
I told you that a cunning man told me, that you should haue a losse, and he has prophicied so true.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Out he's a villaine, to prophecy of the losse of my chaine, twas worth aboue three hundred Crownes,— besides twas my Fathers, my fathers fathers, my Grand-fathers huge grand-fathers? I had as liue ha lost my Neck, as the chaine that hung about it; O my chaine, my chaine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh brother, who can be against a misfortune, tis happy twas no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: No, more! O goodly godly sister, would you had me lost more? my best gowne too, with the cloth of gold-lace? my holiday Gascoines, and my Ierkin set with pearle; no more?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, Brother! you can reade.—

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: But I cannot reade where my chaine is,— what strangers haue beene here? you let in strangers! Theeues, and Catch-poles; how comes it gonne? there was none aboue with mee but my Taylor; and my Taylor will not— steale I hope?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: No he's afrayde of a chaine!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now sirrah, the newes?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O Mistres, he may well be cald a Corporall now, for his corpes are as dead as a cold Capons?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: More happinesse.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sirrah, what's this to my chaine? where's my chaine knaue?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: Your chaine sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My chaine is lost villaine.

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: I would hee were hang'd in chaines that has it then for me? Alasse sir, I saw none of your chaine, since you were hung with it your selfe?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: Out varlet? it had full three thousand Lincks,
I haue oft told it ouer at my praiers:
Ouer and ouer, full three thousand Lincks.

sp.speaker: Frayl.
sp.p: Had it so sir: sure it cannot be lost then; Ile put you in that comfort.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Why why?

sp.speaker: Frayl.
sp.p:
Why if your chaine had so many Lincks, it cannot
chuse but come to light.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Delusion? now long Nicholas wheres my chaine.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why about your Neck, ist not sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: About my neck Varlet. My chaine is lost,
Tis stole away, Ime robd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay Brother show your selfe a man:

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I if it be lost or stole, if he would be patient Mistres I could bring him to a Cunning Kinsman of mine that wouldfetcht againe with a Sesarara.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Canst thou? I will be patient, say where dwells he?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Marry he dwels now Sir, where he would not dwell and he could choose: in the Marshalses sir; but hee's an exlent fellow if he were out, has trauyld all the world ore, he, and beene in the seauen and twenty Prouinces: why he would make it be fetcht Sir if twere rid a thousand mile out of towne.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: An admirable fellow what lies he for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why hee did but rob a Steward of ten groats tother Night, as any man would ha done, and there he lies fort.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: Ile make his peace, a Trifle, Ile get his pardon,
Beside a bountifull reward, Ile about it,
But fee the Clearkes, the Iustice will doe much;
I will about it straight, good sister pardon me,
All will be well I hope, and turne to good,
The name of Coniurer has laid my blood.

div.stage: Enter two seriants to arrest the Scholer George Pyeboord.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: His Hostesses where he lies will trust him no longer, she has feed me to arest him; and if you will accompany me, because I know not of what Nature the Scholler is, whether desperate or swift, you shall share with me Seriant Rauen-shaw, I haue the good Angell to arrest him.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Troth Ile take part with thee then, Sariant, not for the sake of the mony so much, as for the hate I beare to a Scholler: why Seriant tis Naturall in vs you know to hate Scholers: naturall besides, they will publish our imperfections, Knaueryes, and Conveyances altars vpon Scaffolds and Stages.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I and spightfully to; troth I haue wounderd how the slaues could see into our brests so much, when our doublets are buttond with Pewter.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I and so close without yeelding; oh their parlous fellows, they will search more with their wits then a Cunstable with all his officers.

sp.speaker: Put,
sp.p: Whist, whist, whist, Yeoman Dogson, Yeoman Dogson.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Ha, what saies Sariant?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Is he in the Pothecaryes shop stil,

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I, I.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Haue an eye, eye.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: The best is Sariant if he be a true Scholler he weares no weapon I thinke.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, no, he weares no weapon.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Masse, I am right glad of that: 'tas put me in better heart; nay if I clutch him once, let me alone to drage him if he be stiff-necked; I haue beene one of the sixe my selfe, that has dragd as tall men of their hands, when their weapons haue bin gone as euer bastinadoed a Sariant— I haue done I can tel you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Sariant Puttocke, Sariant Puttocke.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Hoh.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Hees comming out single.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Peace, peace bee not to greedy, let him play a little let him play a litle, weele ierke him vp of a sudaine, I ha fisht in my time.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I and caught many a foole Seriant.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I parted now from Nicholas: the chaynes coucht,
And the old Knight has spent his rage vpont,
The widdowe holds me in great Admiration'
For cunning Art: mongst ioyes I am' een lost,
For my deuice can no way now be crost,
And now I must to prison to the captaine, and there—

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Oh— I spoke truer then I was aware, I must to prison indeed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p:
They say your a scholler, nay sir— Yeoman Dogson, haue
care to his armes— youle rayle againe Sariants, and stage 'em: you, tickle their vices.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay vse me like a Gentleman, I'me little lesse.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: You a Gentleman? thats a good Iest ifaith; can a Scholler be a Gentleman,— when a Gentleman will not be a Scholler;— looke vpon your welthy Citizenes sonnes, whether they be Scholers or no, that are Gentlemen by their fathers trades: a Scholler a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay let Fortune driue all her stings into me, she cannot hurt that in me, a Gentleman, is Accidens Inseperabile to my bloud.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: A rablement, nay you shall haue a bloudy rablement; vpon you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Goe, Yeoman Dogson before, and Enter the Action 'ith Counter.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Pray do not hand me Cruelly, Ile goe, Exet Dogson .Whether you please to haue me,

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Oh hees tame let him loose seriant.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Pray at whose sute is this?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why at your Hostisses suite where you lie, Misters Cunnyburrow for bed and boord, the somme foure pound fiue shillings and fiue pence.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I know the somme to true, yet I presumde,
Vpon a farder daie; well tis my starres:
And I must beare it now, tho neuer harder.
I sweare now, my deuice is crost indeed.
Captaine must lie bite: this is Deceytes seed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Come, come away.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray giue me so much time as to knit my garter, and Ile away with you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Well we must be paid for this waiting vpon you, this is no paynes to attend thus.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p:
I am now wretched, and miserable, I shall nere recouer of this disease: hot Yron gnaw their fists: they haue strucke a Feuer into my shoulder, which I shall nere shake out agen I feare me, till with a true Habeas Corpus the Sexton remooue me, oh if I take prison once I shall bee prest to death with Actions, but not so happy as speedilie; perhaps I may bee
forty yeare a pressing till I be a thin old man, that looking through the grates, men may looke through me; all my meanes is confounded, what shall I doe? has my wit serued me so long, and now giue me the slippe (like a Traynd seruant) when I haue most need of 'em: no deuice to keepe my poore carcase fro these Puttocks?— yes, happines, haue I a paper about me now? yes too, Ile trie it, it may hit, Extremity is Touch-stone vnto wit, I, I.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Sfoot how many yards are in thy Gatters, that thou art so long a tying on them? come away sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Troth Seriant I protest, you could neuer ha tooke me at a worse time, for now at this instant, I haue no lawfull picture about me.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Slid how shall me come by our fees then.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: We must haue fees Sirra.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: I could ha wisht ifaith, that you had tooke me halfe an hower hence for your owne sake, for I protest if you had not crost me, I was going in great ioy to receiue fiue pound of a Gentleman, for the Deuice of a Maske here, drawne in this paper, but now, come I must be contented, tis but so much lost, and answerable to the rest of my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why how far hence dwells that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: I, well said seriant, tis good to cast about for mony.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Speake, if it be not far—

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: We are but a little past it, the next street behind vs.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Slid we haue waited vpon you grieuously already, if youle say youle be liberall when you hate, giue vs double fees, and spend vpon's, why weele show you that kindnes, and goe along with you to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: I well said still seriant vrge that.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Troth if it will suffice, it shall be all among you, for my part Ile not pocket a penny, my hostisse shall haue her foure pound fiue shillings, and bate me the fiue pence, and the other fifteene shillings Ile spend vpon you.

sp.speaker: Rauinsh.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good Scholler.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: An excellent Scholler Ifaith; has proceeded very well alate; come, weele along with you.

div.stage: Exeunt with him passing in they knock at the doore with a Knocker withinside.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Who knocks, whos's at doore? we had need of a Porter.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: A few friends here?— pray is the Gentleman your maister within.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, is your businesse to him?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I, he knows it, when he see's me:
I pray you haue you forgot mee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I by my troth sir, Pray come neere, Ile in and tell him of you, please you to walke here in the Gallery till he comes.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Wee will attend his worship,— worship I thinke, for so much the Posts at his doore should signifie, and the faire comming in, and the wicket, else I neither knew him nor his worship, but 'tis happinesse he is within doores, what so ere he bee, if he be not too much a formall Citizen, hee may doe me good: Seriant and Yeoman, how doe you like this house, ist not most wholsomly plotted?

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Troth prisoner, an exceeding fine house.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Yet I wonder how hee should forget me, for hee nere knew mee: No matter, what is forgot in you will bee remembred in your Maister.
sp.l: A pritty comfortable roome this me thinkes:
You haue no such roomes in prison now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Oh dog-holes toote,

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Dog-holes indeed— I can tell you I haue great hope to haue my Chamber here shortly, nay and dyet too, for hee's the most free-hartedst Gentleman where he takes: you would little thinke it? and what a fine Gallery were here for mee to walke and study, and make verses,

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O it stands very pleasantly for a Scholler.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Looke what maps, and pictures, and deuices, and things, neatly delicately? masse here he comes, he should be a Gentleman, I like his Beard well;— All happinesse to your worship.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: You're kindly welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: A simple salutation.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Masse it seemes the Gentleman makes great account of him.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I haue the thing here for you sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I beseech you conceale me sir, Ime vndone else,— I haue the Maske here for you sir, Looke you sir,— I beseech your worship first to pardon my rudenesse, for my extreames makes mee boulder then I would bee; I am a poore Gentleman and a Scholler, and now most vnfortunately falne into the Fangs of vnmercifull officers, arrested for debt, which tho small, I am not able to compasse, by reason Ime destitute of lands, money, and friends, so that if I fall into the hungrie swallow of the prison, I am like vtterly to perish, and with fees and extortions be pincht cleane to the bone: Now, if euer pitty had interest in the bloud of a Gentleman, I beseech you vouchsafe but to fauour that meanes of my escape, which I haue already thought vpon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Goe forward.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I warrant he likes it rarely.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: In the plundge of my extremities, being giddy, and doubtfull what to doe; at last it was put into my labouring thoughts, to make happy vse of this paper, and to bleare their vnlettered eyes, I told them there was a Deuice for a Maske drawne int', and that (but for their interception,) I was going to a Gentleman to receiue my reward for't: they greedy at this word, and hoping to make purchase of me, offered their attendance, to goe along with mee, my hap was to make bolde with your doore Sir, which my thoughts showde mee the most fairest and comfortablest entrance, and I hope I haue happened right vpon vnderstanding, and pitty: may it please your good Worship then, but to vphold my Deuice, which is to let one of your men put me out at back-doore, and I shall bee bound to your worship for euer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: By my troth an excellent deuice.

sp.speaker: Puttock.
sp.p: An excellent deuice hee sayes; hee likes it wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A my faith I neuer heard a better.

sp.speaker: Rauenshaw.
sp.p: Harke, hee sweares hee neuer heard a better, Serieant.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O there's no talke on't, hees an excellent Scholler, and especially for a Maske.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Giue me your Paper, your Deuice; I was neuer better pleasde in all my life: good witte, braue witte, finely rought, come in sir, and receiue your money sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Ile follow your good Worship,—
You heard how he likte it now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Puh, we know hee could not choose but like it: goe thy wayes thou art a witty fine fellow ifaith, thou shalt discourse it to vs at Tauerne anon wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: I, I, that I will,— looke Seriants here are Maps, and prittie toyes, be dooing in the meane time, I shall quickly haue told out the money, you know.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Goe, goe little villaine, fetch thy chinck, I begin to loue thee, Ile be drunke to night in thy company.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: This gentleman I may well call a part
Of my saluation, in these earthly euils,
For hee has sau'd mee from three hungrie Deuils.

sp.speaker: Puttock.
sp.p: Sirrah Seriant, these Mappes are prittie painted things, but I could nere fancie 'em yet, mee thinkes they're too busie, and full of Circles and Coniurations, they say all the world's in one of them, but I could nere finde the Counter in the Poultrie.

sp.speaker: Raue.
sp.p: I thinke so: how could you finde it? for you know it stands behind the houses.

sp.speaker: Dogson.
sp.p: Masse thats true, then we must looke ath' back-side fort; Sfoote here's nothing, all's bare.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I warrant thee that stands for the Counter, for you know theres a company of bare fellowes there.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Faith like enough Seriant? I neuer markt so much before? Sirrah Seriant, and Yeoman, I should loue these Maps out a crye now, if wee could see if peepe out of doore in em, oh wee might haue em in a morning to our Breake-fast so finely, and nere knocke our heeles to the ground a whole day for em.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.l: I marry sir, Ide buye one then my selfe.
But this talke is by the way, where shall's sup to night,
Fiue pound receiu'd, let's talke of that,
sp.p: I haue a trick worth all, you two shall beare him to'th Tauerne, whilst I goe close with his Hostisse, and worke out of her, I know shee would bee glad of the summe to finger money; because shee knowes tis but a desperat debt, and full of hazard, what will you say if I bring it to passe that the Hostisse shall bee contented with one halfe for all; and wee to share tother; fift-shillings bullies.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why I would call thee King of Seriants, and thou shouldst be Chronicled in the Counter booke for euer.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Well put it to me, weele make a Night on't faith.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Sfoote I thinke he receiues more money he staies so long.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Hee tarries long indeed, may be I can tell you vpon the good liking ont the Gentleman may proue more bountifull.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.p: That would be rare, weele search him.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay be sure of it weele search him! and make him light ynough.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Oh here comes the Gentleman; by your leaue sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: God you god den sirs,— would you speake with me;

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, not with your worship sir, only wee are bould to stay for a friend of ours that went in with your worship.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Who? not the scholler?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Yes e'en he and it please your worship?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Did he make you stay for him? hee did you wrong then why, I can assure you hees gon aboue an houre agoe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: How? sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I payd him his money, and my man told me he went out at back-dore.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Back-dore?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: He was our prisoner sir, we did arrest him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: What he was not? you the Sheriffes Officers— you were to blame then,
Why did you not make knowne to me as much:
I could haue kept him for you, I protest
He receiude all of me in Brittaine Gold
Of the last coyning;

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Vengeance dog him with't.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Sfoote has he guld vs so.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Where shall wee sup now Serieants?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Sup Simon now, eate Porridge for a month;
sp.p: Well, wee cannot impute it to any lacke of good-will in your Worship,— you did but as another would haue done, twas our hard fortunes to misse the purchase, but if ere wee clutch him againe, the Counter shall charme him.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: The hole shall rotte him.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So,
Vex out your Lungs without doores, I am proud,
It was my hap to helpe him, it fell fit,
He went not emptie neither for his wit:
Alasse poore wretch, I could not blame his braine,
To labour his deliuerie, to be free,
From their vnpittying fangs— Ime glad it stood,
Within my power to doe a Scholler good.

div.stage: Enter in the Prison, meeting George and Captaine, George comming in muffled.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How now, whos's that? what are you?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: The same that I should be Captaine.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: George Pye-boord, honest George? why camst thou in halfe fac'd muffled so?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Oh Captaine, I thought we should nere ha laught agen, neuer spent frolick houre agen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why? why?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.l: I comming to prepare thee, and with newes
As happy as thy quick deliuerie,
Was trac'd out by the sent, arrested Captaine.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Arrested George.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Arrested, gesse, gesse, how many Dogges doe you thinke Ide vpon me?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dogs, I say? I know not.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Almost as many as George Stone the Beare,
Three at once, three at once.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How didst thou shake 'em of then?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: The time is busie, and calls vpon our witts, let it suffice,
Here I stand safe, and scapt by miracle,
Some other houre shall tell thee? when weele steepe
Our eyes in laughter: Captaine my deuice
Leanes to thy happinesse, for ere the day
Be spent toth' Girdle, thou shalt be set free,
The Corporal's in his first sleepe, the Chaine is mist,
Thy Kinsman has exprest thee, and the old Knight
With Palsey-hams now labours thy release,
What rests, is all in thee, to Coniure Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Coniure: sfoote George you know the deuill a coniuring I can coniure.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: The Deuill of coniuring nay by my fay, Ide not haue thee do so much Captaine as the Deuill a coniuring: looke here, I ha brought thee a circle ready characterd and all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sfoote George, art in thy right wittes, doost know what thou saist? why doost talke to a Captaine, a coniuring, didst thou euer heare of a Captaine coniure in thy life, doost cal't a Circle, tis too wide a thing my thinkes: had it beene a lesser Circle, then I knew what to haue done.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Why euery foole knowes that Captaine: nay then Ile not cogge with you Captaine, if youle stay and hang the next Sessions you may.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No by my faith George, come, come, lets to coniuring, lets to coniuring.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: But if you looke to be releasd, as my wittes haue tooke paine to worke it, and all meanes wrought to farther it, besides to put crownes in your purse, to make you a man of better hopes, and where as before you were a Captaine or poore Souldier, to make you now a Commander of rich fooles, (which is truly the onely best purchase peace can allow you) safer then Hig-wayes, Heath, or Cunny-groues, and yet a farre better bootie; for your greatest theeues are neuer hangd, neuer hangd, for why they're wise, and cheate within doores, and wee geld fooles of more money in one night, then your false tailde Gelding will purchase in a twelue-moneths running, which confirmes the olde Beldams saying, hee's wisest, that keepes himselfe warmest, that is, hee that robs by a good fire.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well opened yfaith George, thou hast puld that saying out of the huske.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Captaine Idle, tis no time now to delude or delay, the old Knight will be here suddenly, Ile perfect you, direct you, tell you the trick on't: tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sfoote George, I know not what to say toot, coniure? I shall be hangd ere I coniure.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay tell not me of that Captaine, youle nere coniure after your hangd, I warrant you looke you sir, a parlous matter? sure! first to spred your circle vpon the ground, then with a little coniuring ceremonie, as Ile haue an Hackney-mans wand siluerd ore a purpose for you, then arriuing in the circle, with a huge word, and a great trample as for instance: haue you neuer seene a stalking-stamping Player, that will raise a tempest with his toung, and thunder with his heeles?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O yes, yes, yes: often, often.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Why be like such a one, for any thing will bleare the old Knights eyes, for you must note that heele nere dare to venture into the roome, onely perhaps peepe fearefully through the Key hole, to see how the Play goes forward.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well I may goe about it when I will, but marke the end ont, I shall but shame my selfe ifaith George, speake big words, and stampe and stare and he looke in at Key-hole, why the very thought of that would make me laugh out-right, and spoile all, nay Ile tell thee George, when I apprehend a thing once, I am of such a laxatiue laughter, that if the Deuill him-selfe stood by, I should laugh in his face.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, thats but the babe of a man, and may easily bee husht, as to thinke vpon some disaster, some sad misfortune, as the death of thy Father ithe Country!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sfoote that would be the more to driue me into such an extasie, that I should nere lin laughing.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Why then thinke vpon going to hanging else.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Masse that's well remembred, now ile do well I warrant thee, nere feare me now: but how shall I do George for boysterous words, and horrible names.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, any fustian inuocations Captaine will serue as well as the best, so you rant them out well, or you may goe to a Pothecaries shop, and take all the words from the Boxes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Troth and you say true George, there's strange words enow to raise a hundred Quack-saluers; tho they be nere so poore when they begin? but here lyes the feare on't, how in this false coniuration a true Deuill should pop vp indeed.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: A true Deuill, Captaine, why there was nere such a one, nay faith hee that has this place, is as false a Knaue as our last Church-warden.
